description: Meaning layer: semantics (encoded meaning) and pragmatics (contextual meaning), with university-level reasoning tools.

topics.name: Semantic Relations
coreClaims: Meaning relations include entailment, contradiction, presupposition, and ambiguity.
Ambiguity can be structural (syntax) or lexical (word meaning).
practice: Test entailment with paraphrase and negation.
Identify ambiguity type and propose disambiguations.

topics.name: Pragmatics and Implicature
coreClaims: Speakers imply more than they state; hearers infer based on norms and context.
Politeness, hedging, and stance are pragmatic tools heavily used in academic writing.
practice: Rewrite a claim with calibrated hedging appropriate for academic prose.
Explain a misunderstanding as a pragmatic mismatch (not just 'bad grammar').
